multi_topic_discovery.topic_discovery_motivation: Impact: commodities; Lumber price decline driven by inventory buildup and tariff threat, feeding US inflation expectations and dollar repricing.

category.motivation: The article discusses potential duties and tariffs on Canadian lumber imports, which constitutes a regulatory change affecting the lumber market.

impact.motivation: The article concerns lumber prices and potential tariffs, but no canonical handle mapping to listed commodity indices or FX, so it is not relevant to the node's scope.

time_frame.motivation: The article focuses on recent price movements and tariff considerations affecting lumber markets.

article_node.title: Lumber Prices Hit 2025 Low
article_node.summary: Lumber prices fell over 20% in August and continued to drop into September, reaching their lowest level this year. The decline is driven by a glut of wood stockpiled ahead of a significant increase in duties on Canadian lumber imports. Speculative inventory buildup across mills and dealers has exacerbated the oversupply. The U.S. government is also considering tariffs on imported lumber under national security pretexts, adding further uncertainty to the market.
